ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If you have a specific conflict you want to research, absolutely take this class. Abbey will improve your writing tremendously. However, it is not the most interesting seminar as a whole.

Take the class if you're interested in issues of displacement, ethnic cleansing, and refugees (as the name suggests). It'll give you a very broad picture and allow you to focus on the areas you're interested in.
It is definitely a class that anyone interested in ethnic cleansing should take. You will learn a great deal about theoretical analysis and be able to apply it to case studies.
Very theoretical, too much so perhaps.

This class is a great class if you can get through a lot of dense theory. While the readings were not necessarily overly lengthy, they took a good amount of time to understand. However, I really liked that this class held me accountable for what I read. The final paper expected that you understood the other main scholars in the field's scholarship well enough to critique it yourself. This definitely challenged me transition to a higher, more rigorous level of thinking, which I think I will benefit from in the future.

An amazing course introducing different ways of looking at ethnic cleansing. I particularly saw this course as a prep course for grad school. Abbey seemed to structure it in such as way as to prepare us for graduate studies in political science. Not only did I learn more about ethnic cleansing, I also learned how to write and think more critically.
